The reason it's not pointy at the top is because it never goes supersonic on the way up. This kind of rounded shape is optimal for air resistance at subsonic speeds. Once you go supersonic, you need that pointy shape.

Just to make sure people know, there is no set orbital velocity. It is dependent on the altitude you want stay above the earth. Obviously some considerations need to be made such as being above the drag of our atmosphere but every other variable in orbital velocity function is a constant to a given central body so velocity is inversely proportional to the square root of orbiting altitude

straight up launch is only terrible if you got low TWR
since you are only fighting gravity when your engine is lit.
if you have an absurd TWR on your upper stage its no problem.

the problem is getting a high TWR on your second stage, this means that your first stage needs to be bigger and thus more expensive.
if a future "magical" engine has high thrust to weight and an order of magnitude better specific impuls.
then a straight op launch would be an acceptable idea if you are short on time.

escape velocity is 11km/s
to get to low earth orbit you need 7 km/s, the energy spent on going into orbit is not wasted because of the energy principle, if you add 4km/s in low earth orbit you will raise your orbit until you reach escape velocity.

One company has some of the most well engineered tech in the industry but has yet to make their mark in space. The other has innovate tech made by rapid iteration, and even if none of their rocket engines are as "good" as Blue Origins, their tech is good enough and they have absolutely disrupted the launch and telecoms market. One of these companies is building unmistakably wonderful tech, and won't stop refining it until the sun burns out. The other is blazing an active path into the future. I didn't mention which is which, but you can probably guess.

To SpaceX, well done on your progress, you're working fast, breaking things, getting results, iterating constantly, and shaping the aerospace launch market. To Blue Origin, you have great tech but haven't moved much. Your window to participate in a free market is closing, and you're falling too far behind. Please, step it up. You have clever engineers and are funded by the world's wealthiest man. Come on!

Calling a wealthy passenger on a rocket an astronaut just because they've been to space is like calling someone a pilot just because they've flown business class.

It doesn't work that way. Astronauts represent the best and brightest of us, and they do relevant technical work in space. I think that's a major difference, and there are other things.

EDIT:

To those saying once you cross the Karman line, you’re an astronaut by definition, you are 100% correct. My comment is just hinting at the fact that how we think about astronauts will surely need to evolve in the coming decades. Fun fact, in the early days, anyone on a plane was called a pilot. Now most such individuals are better termed passengers.

I wish you all the best.

A lot of people don't seem to realise that the Imperial system in the US is derived from the British Imperial System used by the Empire from 1824 to 1965.  Though the British adopted the metric system we still use imperial for the road system and a few other quirks.

All the disparaging comments for Blue Origin, pretty cringe if you ask me. It's fine if you like SpaceX best, they are the strongest contenders. But it's important to remember that a flourishing space industry cannot be solely created by SpaceX alone. It takes everyone. All different types of space business. I'd eat my theoretical hat if SpaceX could do it all. Even Elon has expressed his interest in seeing more competition for space because I think he knows deep down that it takes more than just one team to make his vision of the future a reality. We should be excited in cheering on any company that wants to get involved in business in space, no matter how small their goals are.

I don't think where the capsule lands compared with where the booster lands would be a problem unless there is no wind at all. Both capsule and booster are pushed by the wind, and pushed in the same direction, but, as the booster drops faster, it is subjected to the wind for a shorter time overall, being thus pushed less far than the capsule. The parachutes also help to blow the capsule even farther away in the right direction (away from the booster).

In isolation these sub-orbital hops by Blue Origin are impressive but in terms of number and achievement they pale in comparison to the twelve Falcon 9 launches to LEO and landings so far this year.  Until Blue Origin can launch a payload to orbit on New Shepard and successful land the first stage then I reserve judgement on their claims.  The glacial pace of progress at Blue Origin suggests that SpaceX will get Starship to orbit first.  With a fully operational reusable Starship capable of achieving very low launch costs what future is there for New Shepard or anything else for that matter.

What fraction of energy is bleed off by atmospheric drag, and what fraction by the final rocket firing? How will that ratio change from the small New Shepard and huge New Glenn? I have similar questions on SpaceX Falcon vs Starship, since larger objects have more mass per surface area, so less air friction slowing. I suppose it also depends on how much cargo and fuel you're carrying.

Comments about the shape of it notwithstanding (because, yeah, it is a little funny-looking), a lot of the comments are just imbecilic.

These guys are doing rocket-science and that's *hard*.
So, who are you to criticize how they're doing it?

How many of you are actually doing anything this hard?
How many have actually tried to do anything even remotely this difficult?

These people are doing the work -- doing the job -- and you are *not*.
Who are you to bitch, moan, whine and gripe about their development methodology?

Let's be clear about something. Nobody in Blue Origin owes any of you a *goddamn thing*.
You are entitled to nothing from them. Not daily updates, not any information, not strategy, not data.

They. Owe. You. NOTHING.

There is only one "team" that matters, and that's humanity.
Our future lies in space, and any technology that helps us reach that goal is laudable, and anybody who works on that technology deserves respect.

So, either get to work helping, or sit down and shut up, and let those who can do the work, get on with the job.
